stem: An ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3- 26 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Low pH with elevated PaCO2 and near-normal bicarbonate indicates acute respiratory acidosis without metabolic compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct acute ventilatory failure pattern. | B: HCO3- is not low. | C: Chronic would show elevated HCO3-. | D: No second primary disorder evident.

stem: ABG: pH 7.31, PaCO2 32 mm Hg, HCO3- 16 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
option_d: Mixed respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis
rationale_correct: Low bicarbonate with low pH indicates metabolic acidosis. Reduced PaCO2 reflects compensatory hyperventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct pattern. | B: pH is low, not high. | C: HCO3- is not elevated. | D: PaCO2 is low, not high.
keywords_to_notice: low HCO3- | low pH | low PaCO2

stem: ABG: pH 7.52, PaCO2 28 mm Hg, HCO3- 23 mEq/L. What is the interpretation?
rationale_correct: Elevated pH with low PaCO2 and minimal bicarbonate change indicates acute respiratory alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct hyperventilation pattern. | B: HCO3- not elevated. | C: pH is not low. | D: HCO3- not low.
exam_logic: Match pH direction with primary driver.

stem: ABG: pH 7.36, PaCO2 58 mm Hg, HCO3- 32 mEq/L. What best describes this pattern?
option_a: Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
rationale_correct: Near-normal pH with elevated PaCO2 and elevated bicarbonate indicates chronic respiratory acidosis with renal compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct compensated pattern. | B: Acute would not have elevated HCO3-. | C: PaCO2 elevated contradicts metabolic alkalosis alone. | D: No second primary disorder.
keywords_to_notice: normal pH | high PaCO2 | high HCO3-
exam_logic: Compensation normalizes pH but not gases.

stem: A patient with diabetic ketoacidosis has pH 7.20, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3- 12 mEq/L. Which mechanism explains the acidosis?
rationale_correct: DKA produces ketoacids which consume bicarbonate, producing high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct mechanism. | B: PaCO2 is low, not high. | C: Gastric acid loss causes alkalosis. | D: Would cause alkalosis.
common_trap: Missing cause of high anion gap.
exam_logic: Link clinical context to acid source.

stem: ABG: pH 7.10, PaCO2 70 mm Hg, HCO3- 20 mEq/L. What is the interpretation?
rationale_correct: Severely low pH with elevated PaCO2 and low HCO3- indicates two primary processes.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct mixed disorder. | B: HCO3- is low, not elevated. | C: Compensation would not elevate PaCO2. | D: Chronic would show higher HCO3-.
keywords_to_notice: very low pH | PaCO2 high | HCO3- low

stem: ABG: pH 7.49, PaCO2 44 mm Hg, HCO3- 33 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated pH and elevated bicarbonate indicate metabolic alkalosis. PaCO2 is slightly elevated as compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct. | B: PaCO2 not low. | C: Pattern consistent with single process. | D: HCO3- elevated not decreased.

stem: ABG: pH 7.25, PaCO2 50 mm Hg, HCO3- 21 mEq/L. Expected compensatory PaCO2 for metabolic acidosis would be approximately 1.5 x HCO3- plus 8. Does the PaCO2 match compensation?
rationale_correct: Expected PaCO2 ≈ 1.5(21)+8 = 39.5. Actual 50 is too high, indicating additional respiratory acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct mixed disorder. | B: Compensation inadequate. | C: Formula allows estimation. | D: Pattern not alkalosis.
keywords_to_notice: Winter formula | PaCO2 higher than expected

stem: ABG: pH 7.40, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, PaO2 52 mm Hg, HCO3- 24 mEq/L. What is the primary problem?
rationale_correct: Normal pH and PaCO2 with low PaO2 indicates oxygenation failure without ventilatory problem.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct. | B: PaCO2 normal. | C: HCO3- normal. | D: No acid-base abnormality.

stem: A patient has pH 7.05, PaCO2 65 mm Hg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L and altered mental status. What is the most urgent priority?
rationale_correct: Severe respiratory component with hypercapnia requires immediate ventilatory support to correct acidemia.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because ventilation directly lowers PaCO2. | B: Bicarbonate does not fix ventilatory failure. | C: Oxygen does not correct hypercapnia. | D: Compensation too slow.
